data.text: Contents
Management of endometriosis / MSEGL-21031/ 1.0
Page  of
Introduction

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside of the uterus which induces chronic inflammation. Women may therefore experience symptoms of severe pain or subfertility. Prevalence is between 2-10% of women but may affect up to 50% of women with subfertility.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to guide the investigation and management of endometriosis in the outpatient setting.
Definitions

table_items.text: Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside of the uterus
Cancer antigen 125 (CA125) is a protein found on most ovarian cancer cells that is secreted into the blood stream and can be measured.
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogue injections are used for the management of. numerous gynaecological conditions including: Endometriosis

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
Clinical Director, Clinical Lead for Obstetrics and Gynaecology and Consultant Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

The Clinical Director for Women and Children's Services along with the Clinical Lead for Obstetrics and Gynaecology and the Consultant Obstetrician and Gynaecologists must ensure that all clinical staff are aware of the guideline for the Management of Heavy Menstrual Bleeding. They are responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the Women's Services.
Chief Executive:

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Medical Director:

The Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical and dental staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
Director of Nursing:

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Director of Operations:
The Director of Operations is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document in the clinical areas.
Divisional Clinical Director:

The Divisional Clinical Director is responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Division to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Director is responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Manager

The Divisional General Manager is responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Division to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Head of Midwifery and Gynaecology, Matrons, Ward Managers, Midwifery Sisters and Senior Nurses

The Head of Midwifery and Gynaecology is responsible, along with the Matrons, Ward Managers, Midwifery Sisters and Senior Nurses for the implementation of this guideline within the Women's Health CSU.
Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers:

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service Unit and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Lead Nurses:

Lead Nurses are responsible for ensuring that all nursing staff (including Nurse Specialists, Practitioners/Advisors) within the Clinical Service Unit comply with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurse will make sure that all necessary training is provided.
Medical Staff
The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow this document.
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case
Endometriosis

Endometriosis is often a long term chronic condition which can have significant associated morbidity. It can have a significant physical, psychosexual and social impact on the woman. Women may have complex needs and may require long term support.
Diagnosis is based upon the woman's history, symptoms and signs and corroborated by examination, imaging and finally histological diagnosis.
A diagnosis of endometriosis can be considered in patients who present with the following:
Chronic pelvic pain
Dysmenorrhoea affecting daily activities
Deep dyspareunia
Cyclical gastro-intestinal symptoms/ urinary symptoms
Dyschezia ( pain on defaecation) / dysuria
Infertility associated with the above symptoms
Gynaecological services
Women with suspected endometriosis should be referred to a gynaecologist with expertise in diagnosing and managing endometriosis, including laparoscopic surgery.
The following should also be available were possible:
Gynaecology specialist nurse with special interest in endometriosis.
A multidisciplinary pain management service
A healthcare professional with an interest in gynaecological imaging
Fertility services
Onward referral to an endometriosis centre where necessary.
Endometriosis information and support
Where possible and if the woman agrees, their partner (and /or family support members where relevant) should be included in discussions about management.

Women with suspected endometriosis should be offered written information and individualised support, taking into account their individual symptoms, priorities, desire for fertility and social background.
Written information should be offered to women with suspected or confirmed endometriosis (which is available to staff on the Hub/ intranet/ Staffnet).This should include information regarding:
What endometriosis is
Symptoms and signs of endometriosis
How endometriosis is diagnosed
Treatment options
Local Support groups/ online forums and national charities
Diagnosis
The presentation of endometriosis can be varied from woman to woman. Women should be encouraged to keep a pain and symptom diary to aid diagnosis.
Young women aged  and under should also be considered if their symptoms are suggestive of endometriosis. Onward referral to the local paediatric gynaecology service can be considered in this setting.
A diagnosis of endometriosis can be considered in patients who present with the following:
Chronic pelvic pain
Dysmenorrhoea affecting daily activities
Deep dyspareunia during or after intercourse
Cyclical gastro-intestinal symptoms/ urinary symptoms
Dyschezia ( pain on defaecation) / dysuria
Infertility associated with the above symptoms
Examination

Offer pelvic examination to aid diagnosis (including a speculum examination). This may demonstrate endometriotic deposits or masses in the posterior fornix, utero- sacral ligaments, Pouch of Douglas and recto-sigmoid.
Where pelvic examination is not appropriate or is declined (such as in younger patients) , offer abdominal examination to exclude abdominal masses.
A negative pelvic examination does not necessarily exclude endometriosis.
Imaging

Trans-vaginal ultrasound (TVS) should be used as the primary modality to investigate for pelvic endometriosis and to identify pelvic endometriomas. However, a normal scan however, does not exclude endometriosis and further investigation should be sought if symptoms are persistent.
TVS is recommended to confirm or exclude ovarian endometrioma.
Trans-abdominal ultrasound should be offered if TVS is not appropriate.
In patients who present with signs of rectal endometriosis, TVS can be beneficial in identifying or ruling out rectal endometriosis.

MRI should not be used in the primary investigation but should be considered in the diagnosis of deeper endometriosis affecting the bowel, bladder or ureter. MRI imaging should be interpreted by a radiologist specialising in gynaecological imaging.
For women with suspected deep endometriosis, consider ultrasound or MRI before operative laparoscopy.
CA125
CA125 should not be requested to diagnose endometriosis. However, if it has been co-incidentally requested, a CA125 > 35iu may indicate endometriosis.
Diagnostic laparoscopy

Diagnostic laparoscopy can be considered, even if ultrasound does not show evidence of endometriosis. A systemic inspection should be performed, and biopsies should be taken for histological examination to confirm endometriosis or to exclude malignancy.
Where endometriosis is diagnosed, the description, appearance and site of the endometriosis should be clearly documented.
Where laparoscopy is normal, it should be explained to the woman that she does not have endometriosis and an alternative management plan should be offered.
Offer treatment according to the woman's' symptoms and preferences as the priority rather that the stage of endometriosis.
Consider outpatient follow up for women with confirmed endometriosis, particularly women with
Deep endometriosis involving bowel, bladder, ureter
Endometrioma > 3cm
Management of endometriosis
Women with endometriosis suffer with pain or subfertility or a combination. The management of this condition should therefore be considered with this in mind.
Management of Pain symptoms
Endometriosis -related pain may include dysmenorrhoea, dysuria, dyschezia,
dyspareunia and non-menstrual pelvic pain. Extra-peritoneal manifestations should also be considered.
Analgesics
The risks and benefits of starting regular analgesics should be discussed with the woman, with consideration for any existing co-morbidities which she may have.

Initially, a trial of paracetamol or NSAIDS should be commenced as first line management for endometriosis pain. However, if this inadequate, consider other forms of pain management or referral for further assessment.
Hormonal treatments
Endometriosis is a generally considered to be an oestrogen dependent process and therefore hormonal contraceptives can be considered in in its management, depending on the woman's preferences.
It should be explained to women that hormonal treatment can alleviate pain and has no permanent negative effect on subsequent fertility.

The use of the combine oral contraceptive pill has been shown to be beneficial in reducing dyspareunia, dysmenorrhoea and non-menstrual pelvic pain It can also be used continuously (back to back packets without a break) to alleviate
dysmenorrhoea. Similarly, consideration may be given to insertion of ring or contraceptive patch for reducing dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia and chronic pelvic pain.

The use of progestogens can be used in reducing endometriosis pain. Depot or oral preparations, cyproterone acetate and norethisterone can all be recommended in endometriosis related pain. Patient however should be counselled regarding the potential side effects of progestogens.
Levonorgestrel IUS can be considered in treating endometriosis related pain.
GnRH analogues

GnRH analogues can be beneficial in reducing endometriosis-associated pain. Consideration should be given towards the anti-oestrogenic side effects such as hot flushes and bone density reduction. Add-back HRT therapy should therefore be offered along-side commenced GnRH analogues.
The optimum duration and dosage are unestablished. However, convention normally limits the duration to 6 months to prevent ongoing bone demineralisation.
Surgical management
Where surgical management is offered, the following should be discussed with the woman:
What a laparoscopy involves
That the laparoscopy may include surgical management ( with patient consent)
How surgery could affect endometriosis symptoms
The risks and benefits of laparoscopy
Potential need for further future surgery ( especially with deep endometriosis)
If endometriosis is suspected, laparoscopy should be considered, even if ultrasound is normal and pain is persistent.
Patients should be counselled about their preferences and priorities with regards to their symptoms and fertility, in order to guide management.
There is no evidence to support pre-operative use of GnRH agonists to improve surgery however, it may improve patient pain whilst they are on the waiting list.
If deep endometriosis is suspected, an MRI should be requested prior to laparoscopy.
Laparoscopy should be offered over laparotomy as this confers a shorter length of stay, less pain and better cosmesis.

Where endometriosis is noted at laparoscopy, it should be surgically treated as this can be effective in reducing endometriotic pain (see and treat approach). Patients should be appropriated consented accordingly.
Where endometriosis is noted at laparoscopy, consider taking a biopsy. This can confirm the diagnosis of endometriosis and also exclude the possibility of malignancy in an endometrioma.
Removal of ovarian endometrioma (>3cm) is associated with reduced recurrence of pain and recurrence of endometrioma. Therefore, consider excision rather than ablation.
If a full, systematic laparoscopy is performed and is normal, explain to the woman that she does not have endometriosis, and offer alternative management
Combination therapy for secondary disease prevention

Following laparoscopic excision or ablation of endometriosis, the woman can be advised to commence hormonal treatment (such as the COCP or IUS) as this can prolong the benefit of surgery and prevent disease recurrence.
Hysterectomy

There is no robust evidence supporting the role of hysterectomy (+/- oophorectomy) in the management of endometriosis and women should be counselled accordingly. It should therefore be considered for patients who have completed their family and in whom conservative management has been unsuccessful.
Women should be counselled regarding:
Where hysterectomy is indicated, excise all visible endometriotic lesions at the time of hysterectomy.
Perform hysterectomy laparoscopically where possible, unless contra-indicated.
Management of subfertility

Subfertility is a significant presentation in women with endometriosis. It is associated with up to 50% of women with subfertility. Initially, women should be referred to the specialist subfertility clinic for initial baseline assessment (refer to subfertility guidelines or equivalent)
Hormonal treatment

19.2.1 There is no evidence to support the use of hormonal therapy (such as the combined pill or Mirena coil) in the treatment of endometriosis-related infertility (where a woman is trying to conceive). It does not increase the rate of spontaneous pregnancy.
Surgical treatment
Where endometriosis has been identified, and does not affect the bowel, bladder, ureter, offer excision or ablation of endometriosis as this increases the chance of spontaneous pregnancy

Offer laparoscopic excision of ovarian endometriomas (with excision of the cyst wall) as this can increase the rate of spontaneous pregnancy and reduce recurrence. The patient should be counselled about risk of reduced ovarian function and possible loss of ovary. Consideration should therefore be given to the woman's ovarian reserve.
Discuss the risks and benefits of laparoscopic surgery in women with deep endometriosis to the bowel/ bladder/ ureter who are trying to conceive. This may include:
Whether laparoscopic surgery may alter the chance of future pregnancy
The impact on ovarian reserve
The possible impact on fertility if complications arise
Alternatives to surgery
Other fertility factors
Patient who are found to have deep endometriosis should be referred to the regional endometriosis centre as this may require further assessment and specialised management.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

This guideline will be monitored and audited by the Advanced Specialist Midwife – Audit and Research and the Clinical Lead Consultant. Where audit has identified any deficiencies, recommendations and action plans will be developed and changes implemented accordingly.

The Advanced Specialist Midwife – Audit and Research is responsible for reporting the outcome of audits and progress against action plans to the Women's Health Clinical Governance Group. Changes will be highlighted to all relevant staff through Head of Midwifery and Gynaecology and Obstetrics Consultants. Any barriers to implementation will be risk assessed and where necessary added to the Women's Health Risk Register.

Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Women's Health Clinical Governance and Risk Group (WHCGRG) and Divisional Governance and Performance Board (DGPB).
Women's Health Clinical Governance and Risk Group (WHCGRG)

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Maternity and Gynaecology Policy Working Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local maternity and gynaecology speciality guidelines.

The Women's Health Clinical Governance and Risk Group will be notified of approved guidelines and when they are uploaded to the Controlled Document Centre on The Hub, Document Centre (staff intranet).
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix
